div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: FIGHTING AT SANDEPU. RUSSIAM RETREAT HEAVY LOSSES
div.p: Murden, January 30. The Japanese losses at Sandepu amounted to 5,000 and the Russian to 10,000. ( Havas. )

St. Petersburg, January 30. A despatch from General Gripenberg shows that the Japanese have vigorously attacked the Russians. General Koudratovitch has been wounded. (Reuter) Tokio, January 30. T The Japanese estimate their losses during the recent fighting at 5,000 and the Russians at 10,000. (Reuter).
London, January 30. Router s correspondent with General Kuroki says that after driving the Russians across the Hun-Ho the Japanese bombarded the whole line. The Russian reply was feeble. (R.)

div.head: RIOTS AT WARSAW. TERRIBLE CARNAGE. OUTRAGE ON BRITISH CONSUL
div.p: Warsaw, January 30. Serious riots occurred here on Saturday. Many of the finest shops were sacked and burned. The cavalry charged, and the troops fired, at several points of the town. Mr. Murray, the British: Consul-General, and Mr. St. Clair, the Vice-Consul, were separately charged by patrols. The Vice-Consul received terrible sword cute in the face. (Reuter).

St. Petersburg, January 30. Sir C. Hardinge has sent a military attache to Warsaw in order to investigate the reported attacks on the British Consul-General and Pro-consul by the soldiers. Sir C. Hardinge has protested against the re-publication at Libau of the notices mentioned on the 26tb inst, pointing out that such a step will seriously affect the friendly relations between the two countries. (Reuter.)
Warsaw, January 30. Disturbances have been renewed to-day. There were 160 killed and wounded. The troops at Libau have been reinforced as the situation is worse. (Reuter).

div.head: ECHO OF THE RUSSIAN REVOLT. OUTRAGE IN PARIS.
div.p: Paris, January 30. At the close of the meeting organised by M. Jaures to protest against the events in St Petersburg, an infernal machine was thrown amidst the policemen, two of whom wen wounded. Four arrests were made. The police found an infernal machine during the night at the residence of Prince Troubzkoi, attache to the Russian Embassy (Havas.)

div.head: SIR FRANCIS JEUNE. TO RECEIVE A PEERAGE.
div.p: London, January 30 Sir Francis Jeune has resigned. He is to receive a peerage. (Reuter.)

div.head: WARING GILLOW, LIMITED. DECORATORS AND FURNISHERS TO HIS MAJESTY THE KING.
div.p: Beg to announce to their clients that the director of their Paris House, Mr. Cauldwell, is at present-at the New Khodivial Hotel, Alexandria, where he can be seen by appointment by those desiring his artistic advice on all matters connected with 'decoration and furnishing. Waring and Gillow lately tarnished the Palace of Prince Nicholas of Greece at Athens. Mr. Cauldwell will be at Shepherd’s Hotel, Cairo, after February 3rd to meet clients. 25373-6-1

div.head: Gambling Den Raided
div.p: On Sunday night the police of the Esbekieh kism made a raid on a gambling house occupied by a Greek subject in the Sharia Weiget el Birks.

div.head: New Doctors
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has licensed Messrs. Herbert William Hughes Robert Brabant, physician, Jean Auaguosto-Poulo and Mohauied Satnch, dentists, to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Khedivial Opera House
div.p: It is stated that if it is decided to pull down the Khedivial Opera House at Cairo, tho new theatre will be Obstructed, not in the Khedivial Gardens, but in either the Ismail is or the Kasr-el-Nil quarter.

div.head: Savot Small Dances
div.p: Next Saturday's dance at the Savoy Hotel promises to be as successful as in predecessors. Most of the tables in jlio restaurant' are already engaged for this evening. There will be an extra small dance next Tuesday.

div.head: Alexandria Sporting Club
div.p: The annual general meeting of the club will bo held at the Khedivial Club on the 15th February at 9 p m , when the balance-sheet and the accounts of the past year will be laid before the meeting and the officers and the committee for the ensuing year elected.

div.head: Matinee Concert
div.p: Mme. J. de Wronocka will give a vocal and instrumental matinee concert on the 8th proxo at the Savoy Hotel, Cure. Mme. Wronocka has given a very successful series of concerte in Franco and Italy. Tickets are obtainable at the Savoy.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 30 vessels passed through the Canal on the 26th and 27th inst, of which 17 were British, 4 German, 2 Norwegian, 1 Austrian, 2 French, 1 Dutch, 2 Turkish, 1 Dani-b. The receipt for the two days were frs. 739,195.76, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 9,854,370.68.

div.head: Tram Wires
div.p: The electric wire at the Boulac train terminus snapped on Sunday, some 20 metres coming down on the roadway. M. George Vayssi4 narrowly escaped being struck, but coolly fended off the falling wire with his cane. We congratulate him on his escape, but—might not the Tramway Company give us guard-wires.

div.head: Popular University
div.p: The second of the lectures organised under the patronage of the Alexandria Archaeological Society will take place to-morrow at 9.15 p.m., when Dr. Brescia, Conservator of the Alexandria Museum, will speak on “Greek Colonisation in Sicily." The lecture will be illustrated by lime light view*. Entrance is tree.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: THE MIXED COURTS.
div.p: Renewal of powers. The existence of the Mixed Courts has been renewed for a further term of five years, and not for one year only, as some newspapers have stated. The date of the coming into force of the various reforms, agreed upon by the Judicial Commission, has not yet been fixed upon. Yesterday the Government informed the Appeal Court of the renewal of the executive of the Mixed Court*. The new term of five year* begins tomorrow. The Decree authorising the renewal of the functions of the Courts was signed by the Khedive yesterday.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is expected to return to Cairo from M-mtazah on Thursday next. His Highness has been pleased to confer the following grade and decorations:— Ramiek: Osman Anwar Mahfoux Bey, notable of Cairo. Medjidiek: Commander (3rd class): M. Louis, Soul iAre, of the Paris police. Officer (4th class): M. Francois Rameau, chief inspector, Paris police. M. Hally, chef de bureau Prefecture of Paris police. Chevalier(5th class): M. Antonin Guerra, M. Andres Paul; and M. Henri Chatelain, Paris police. Signor Tihaldi, the violinist, played before the Khedivial in the Khedivial Palace at Be-hek, on the Bosphorus, a few days ago. The Khedivah and her suite, who were separated from Signor Tihaldi by a large screen, greatly appreciated his playing. Before leaving the palace, the Khedivah presented Signor Tihaldi with a magnificent stud oomposed of a huge emerald surrounded with beautiful brilliants. She also presented Professor Selvelli with a set of jewelled sleeve-links.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The provincial councils of Keneh, Assiout, Beni Souef, Girgeh, and Ghizeh met on Sunday morning at their respective Mondiriehs, and after taking the oath, proceeded to elect their d-legates to the Legislative Council. The following delegate was re-elected for Assistance: Mahmoud Pasha Suliman. Hassan Bey Bakri was elected for Keneh, Mobamed Bey Tammam for Girzeh, Tamara Bey Kussad for Beni Souef and Mohamed Buy El Maihi for Ghizeh.

div.head: NILE NAVIGATION.
div.p: The Irrigation Service has decided to construct a sadd across the Rosetta brooch of the Nile at Mehallet el Amir, kilometre 215 downstream on the Delta Barrage. Navigation on the Rosette branch of the Nile will be interrupted at the above-mentioned place during such time as the sadd will be maintained there. A part of the above-mentioned sadd will be specially affected to transhipment of goods arriving on boats. This transhiment will be carried out at the risk and peril, at the expense, and by the care of tbe owners of the Mats or the goods. The sadd will be dosed about the 10th February and will be removed about the 15th August. The Irrigation Service having decided to construct a sadd across the Nile at Farascour, near Damietta, navigation on the Damietta branch at Farscour will be interrupted between February 15 and August 15.

div.head: RAMLEH RAILWAY.
div.p: The plan of a station at the company’s new terminus on the Ramleh-boulevard was submitted to the Municipality yesterday and will be examined by the Delegation today. It is proposed to build the station of brick and it will be of an artistic design. Meanwhile, a temporary wooden building has been erected.

div.head: THE ORIENT LIKE.
div.p: The rumour that the steamers of the Orient-Pacific Line were about to substitute the Cape route homeward bound for that of the Suez Canal is incorrect. We learn that the steamers of the line continue to come home through the Suez Canal as heretofore. The steamers will leave here every fortnight, as before, and homeward-bound Egyptian passengers may rely upon an equally good service this year as in the past. We may mention that the "Oroya," leaving here about February 28, to the "Orizaba" inclusive, will call at Malta in addition to the usual ports of call homeward bound, bat there will be very little delay entitled by this extra call.

div.head: ENGLISH CHURCH, MANSOURAH. SERVICES IN FEBRUARY.
div.p: 5th (5th Sunday after Epiphany). Evensong at 6 p.m. 12th (6th Sunday after Epiphany). Litany and H.C. at 11 am. 19th Septoagerima. Evensong at 6 p.m. 26th Sexagesima. H.C. at 8 am. Matina at 11 am. T. D. C. Firhinger, Chaplain.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR
div.p: Beet and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges Patronised by office' of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: THE WADY RAYAN AND MR. COPE WHITEHOUSE.
div.p: A correspondent writes: In regard to the article on Mr. Cope Whitehouse which appeared in Friday's “Gazette,” I may mention that historians of the future should not overlook the fact that there is one man to whom Egypt is much indebted as to anyone for the Assouan dam, and that is Mr. Cope Whitehouse. Ho is a man ot very great mental capacity, equally fitted to fill a professorship of Greek or Natural Science. Twenty ago be foresaw the necessity of storage rsaenoira for Egypt and proposed the Wady Rayan for this purpose. His inveterate persistency caused the Irrigation Department to face the alternative of either adopting his scheme or of bringing forward a better one of their owe. That his scheme bad valuable features wm proved by Colonel Western’s investigation, and Sir William Willeocks now strongly supports it as a necessary complement of the existing Assocan dam. Without the slightest doubt Mr. Cope Whitehouse’s advocacy of a reservoir, even admitting a neglect of the maxim “Snaviter in modo, fortiW in re,’’ led to Egypt having a reservoir at a mnoh earlier date than would otherwise have occurred. Not long ago the representatives of M. De la Motte unsuccessfully sued the Egyptian Government for a share of profit from the Assouan dam. The De la Motte scheme was for a reservoir at Gebel 8ilseleh, but it was based on date not adopted by the International Commission which stadied the whole question of reservoir. Mr. Cope Whitehouse’s scheme in many respects stood the test of searching technical engineer, and it may some day become a “fait accompli." Be that as it may, Egypt is deeply indebted to him for forcing on a solution of the reservoir question, even if his scheme was not the first to be adopted.

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT.
div.p: An official notice has been issued by which Ahmed Bey Khaled has been deprived of his functions as treasurer of the "Surra.”

div.head: CAIRO TRAFFIC.
div.p: At last the work of asphalting Clot Beystreet,Cairo, has been finished and the thorough. Care has been reopened to traffic. The improvement effected is very great. Formerly the street was one of the worst in Cairo, and everybody knows well what that means. A drive through it in an ordinary hackney carriage, thanks to the ruts and boles that abounded, was not unlike having a cruise in a small boat on a rough day, and the wear and tear on vehicles of every kind was as disastrous to them as it was cruel to the unfortunate animals that had to drag them over the broken roadway. So far as one can judge from appearance the asphalting has been thoroughly well done and promises to prove a success. The entire surface has been laid from footpath to footpath, the only break in the asphalt being the lines of the Tramway Company. Whether it would not have been better to have laid the spaces between the tram lines with stone is a question that experience only can decide, but there seems some danger of a rapid deterioration of the asphalt by the breaking of the edges that it presents all along at both sides of each of the tram lines. The resumption of the services of the Tramway Company by this route has been accomplished without a hitch, and the great pressure upon the traffic of the Esbekieh quarter of late has thus been relieved. One result of the temporary service, however, has been to show that there is a real need for a tram service connecting the A tabs el Khadra and the railway station via Boulac-road, as this would enable travelers by the cars to reach the centre of the Esbekieh district from all quarters of the town, whereas by the now-existing routes this can only be done from the Citadel or Boulac. This is a question well worthy the attention of the company.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL CLUB DANCE.
div.p: The dance given last night by the members of the Khedivial Clob, Alexandria, forming, u it did, one of the first large social functions of the season, was a brilliant success in every respect. The palatial premises were most profusely and tastefully decorated with innumerable plants and shrubs and illuminated 1 jour by hundreds of electric lamps. The sitting rooms, benefits, etc., were transformed into gardens and the billiard tables covered with tastefully selected small plants. The floor and D’Ambra’s orchestra were excellent and the large dancing room presented a brilliant coup I ceil by 11.30 o’clock, when dancing was in mil awing. This was kept up with great animation until 8.80 o’clock this morning. It would be a difficult teak to give even a slight description of the beautiful view or their brilliant effect. More than 300 guests were present, including almost every leading representative of Alexandria and Ramleh society. the members of the Consular Corps, Municipal Councillors, the Colonel and officers of the Royal Berkshire Regiment, and the officers of the Royal Malta Artillery and R. A. M. C., etc. Sapper was served in three different rooms, nicely arranged for the occasion. The whole arrangement of the evening reflected the greatest credit upon the committee and also upon their secretary, Mr. Albert Cumbo, and hi* assistant, Mr. Borg, whose indefatigable energy had, as usual, ensured the success which attended the evening's functions.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: We cannot say that Rigoletto was anything but a complete failure as given at the Khedivial Opera House. We admit that the chorus was good and the staging fine, but then this theatre can afford such luxuries. Signoi Andreini was never pleasing, and not always in time: and his rendering of "La donna in time" was the climax of exasperation, both inartistic and unmusical. Signora Tromben should never have attempted the part of Gilda; she did all she could, but it was far beyond her voice. We regret greatly that we should have to criticise her, at it was so obvious that the did her. Vary beat in “Caro nome,” and foiled hopelessly. Signor Nani was fairly good, be boa a fine strong voice, and the part, on the whole, suite him ; but hit vibrato is excessive and jarring at limes : a ban tone should, undoubtedly, be something more than merely forcible. Still, his acting and singing were the only redeeming features of the performance, and he deceived his encore in Act IU. We cannot close this perfomance(it it fully borne out by the attitude of the audience) without alluding to the for more excellent performance of Rigvletto by the Verdi Theatre company. Signora Sricher is of entree a phenomenon, and her rendering of “Caro nome” is unique: not only did she exhibit a wonderful delicacy and clarity of tone, but she performed the tour de fort of taking the final note in octavo I and that apparently without effort. But the real reason for mentioning the Verdi Theatre is that the other “principals" were to good. Signor Tomisani’s “La donna a mobile" could not have been bettered for tone and phrasing: it was encored by an audience who, we are certain, were distinctly prejudiced against him. Signori Bad in and Baldelli were aa good and better than their own peers of the Khedivial Theatre, as Rigolatto and the Bravo. And yet these three gentlemen are probably quite unknown. We take this opportunity of informing our reader* that it is quite possible the Verdi Theatre company will revisit Cairo, after their stay in Alexandria, and we announce all who may not be "abound” at the State Opera to go, just once or twice, to hear them. We are certain they will confirm our opinion, and will not regret the expenditure of half the sum exacted by the Khedivial Opera House, for an inferior rendering at that 1 , Tristano e Ieotta was given for the second fame on Thursday night Taking all things into consideration, it was a satisfactory enough performance. Tristan himself and Hurrenaldo being both excellent, though Tristan was hardly sufficiently audible in the 1st act To our thinking Signore Pinto marred her part by excessive vibrato, though happily this was less conspicuous in the 2nd act, which was the best part of the performance. The Liebes Tod can hardly be pronounced a success: in foot, Signora Pinto was scarcely audible, and indeed all through, though the Orchestra was distinctly good, there was a certain neglect of the proper emphasis. The sailor’s chorus left much to be desired. However, we must not apply German standards to an Italian company, to whom a Wagner opera is only an incident in the announcement and so, keeping this foot in view, we can pronounce’ the performance distinctly creditable.

div.head: SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL
div.p: The grand cotillon ball at Shepheard’s Hotel last night was a splendid success and reflected the greatest credit on the management of the hotel. Among the many dinner parties given in the restaurant prior to the ball were those of Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish with a party of four, Count Sakakini Pasha and party at six, Count Kocziedroczki, the Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-general, and party of five, Baron de Wecker and friends, Major Kenny Herbert and largo party, Major Lawson and party of four, Mr. D. K. Reid and a party of eight, Mr. Meimareohi and a large party, Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Milward and seven friends, Dr. and Mrs. Madden entertaining six friends, Mr. A. G. Morton at the head of a table of four, Mr. Edgar Anderson with a number of friends, and many others. The ball began at about 9.30 o’olook and lasted until an early hoar this morning.

div.p: The following passengers left Cairo today by the “Ramoses": —Miss E A. Atwater, Mrs. Geeland de la Bistarte, Mr. Blie Cattaui, Dr. Crawford, Mr. and Mrs. Wm. D. Card, Mr. Augustus G. Cobh, Mr. Robert Clark, Miss M. C. Crosfield, Mrs. I. N. and Master Ditten-hoefor, Mr. Newman Erb, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. Bulhry, Mr. and Mrs. Karl von Eisenstaedter, Mr. and Mrs. Geo. H. Fisher, Mite P. Soamee, Min Lacre Sober, Miss Spalding, Mr. and Mr*. R.P. Sullivan, Mines Snnn and Prenoes E. 8ullivan, Dr. Jerome and Mrs. Stonborongh, Mr. and Mrs. Snmmerfield. Mr. and Mr*. C. 8. 8pear, Mrs. D. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Dalhourie entertained a party at dinner at the Savoy Rcteurent yesterday evening. The guests including Sir WU-ham E Garetin, Capt. the Hoc Stanley the Hon. and Mrs. 0. Stanley, etc. Mr. and lira. Coat* also had a large party at dinner, among their guests being Count and Countess Wedal. Among the passengers who arrived at Alexandria yesterday by Alex “Hohensollern" were the Chamberlain to the Tsar, Baron L de Knorring, Count and Countess da Hohenstein. The Marquis de Jacome Correa, Qeherel O’Connor, Countess Care Aroim.-and a number of others whose names will be found in the list of passengers in another column. Sir Thomas Lipton is leaving Cairo today. Sir Thomas has been staying at the Savoy Hotel since last Tuesday, and was in the Empress Eugenie’s party. The suite of the Empress Eugenia contains two famous names in Napoleonic history. The Princess de la Moekowa comes of the family of Napoleon’s great Marshal Ney, who received the title of Prince of Moekowa for the part he played in the Battle of Borodino, which was waged in the valley of the Kolotta, an affluent of the Moekowa. The present head of the house of Ney is the Duke. Mile de Baasano, another of the ex Empress’s suite, belongs to the dneal family of Bassano, the dukedom having been bestowed in 190S on Maret, who was subsequently (1811-1814) Minister of Foreign Affaire. Mr. Waldorf Astor is expected at the 8avof Hotel next Tuesday. Sir Robert and Lady Harvey left the Savoy. Hotel yesterday evening for Upper Egypt Mr. Joseph Walton, M.P., left for England today by the. P. 0. steamer. Mr. Walton spent some time at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, and was also as for aa Khartoum. ^ ’ Yesterday's arrivals at the 8avoy Hotel include Baron von Knoring, Major General Sir Stanley, Clark, Marches di Rudjni, Mr. A. a Horatmann, Mr. A. W. Sohmitx, Mr. Justice and Mrs. Simpeon,Capt and Mia. H.C. French. Sir William Garetin is preparing for a journey to the Sudan early in February. Lady Blomfield second musical party took place yesterday afternoon and crowded with her friends of all nationalities gathered to' hear the musical fore provided by her. We announced amongst some 200 guests H- E the Governor of Alexandria, Brig.-Geueroi Bullock, C.B, Col. McCracken and the offioers of the Royal Berts, Mme. Girard, M» Gould, Baroness von HumboldtDacliroeden, Saba Pasha and Miss Saba, Peake Key, Msjor Hopkinaon and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinaon, Mrs. Borchgrevink, Mrs. Sidney Carver, Mrs. Mantell, Mrs. Preston, Major and Mrs. Gamble, (Jo un teas Zinnia, -Barones* Jacques de Menaaoe, Mr*. Chats way, Mme. Emmanuel Zervudaehi, Mme George* Zervudachi, Mme. Michel Sinodino, Mare Salvago, Mme. Miohel Salvago, Baron and Baroness Alfred de Menaaoe, Dr. uid Mm# Brescia, Rev. Reginald Rynd, Rev. Ronald Wonnell, Mrs. Strickland, Mr and Mrs. G. Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Adamson, etc. Tbe programme of 14 items was varied and interesting and the Queen of Song of these porta, Mme. Briend, outshone benefit and had to sing several gems out of her extensive repertoire after the programme had been gone through, to satisfy her enthusiastic admirers. Mr. H. Scott-Leslie has arrived at Lax or. We are pleased to announce the- birth of a son to Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Cboremi. Both mother and child are progressing The Horn Grevflle Nugent and Mrs: Nugent are staying at the 8avoy Hotel, Luxor. Among other visitors at that hotel we notice i Mr. and Mrs. Tamblyn, Mr. H. Allen, Mr. Murphy, Dr. Malvani, Mr. and Miss Trefogli, Mr. Rova, Mr. M. Dahl, Mr. and Mrs. Hurl bat, Mrs. and Miss Haldane, Mr. R. H. Hompson, Mrs. Napier Sturt, Mr. Wild* Mrs. Bogotioa, Mr. and Mias Fagodios, Mr. and Mrs. Dr. 8tonic, Mia* Beresford, Mrs. Hugh 8mith, Copt, and Mrs. Baring, Ccmte de Malvezxi, Mr. Duval Paul, Mrs. M. da la MaasoolAre, Mr. Alex. Sarrortianou. Mr. W. Actoo-Adams and Miss Edith Collins are among the visitor* at GhezirSh Palace. Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern. Exchange Hotel, Port 8aid, are Mia# 0. N. Rayne, Mr. and Mrs. Botleazor, Mr. J. K Snelus, Mr. D. Lee, Mr. G. H. Malcolm, Hhu K J. Cozed, Mrs. B. Babcock, Mr. KDawaon, Mr. A. Roraoni, Mr. M. De Uvalette, Mr. M. Morduoovitcb, Mr. P. div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.
